title: 114_hr2332
content: The Act titled "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program under the Secretary of Transportation. Grants can be awarded to state governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects like highway or bridge improvements that significantly impact metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects, including interstate rehabilitation, rural road improvements, bridge reconstruction, seismic retrofit projects, public transportation projects, rail transportation projects, port infrastructure investments, aviation infrastructure projects, and water infrastructure projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for various infrastructure projects, including port, aviation, and water infrastructure investments. The Secretary will coordinate grants for water projects with the EPA and Army. Entities must submit applications meeting specified criteria to be eligible for grants. The Secretary will issue regulations for grant criteria within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Financial commitments from non-Federal sources will be considered. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 100 percent. Grants will be awarded based on specified criteria. The Secretary will issue regulations for grant criteria within 90 days of the Act's enactment, considering financial commitments from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 100 percent. Grants will be awarded based on specified criteria, ensuring equitable distribution geographically, addressing urban and rural needs, promoting veteran training and employment, and supporting small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. Each project funded by a grant must comply with Title 40. The grant amounts must be expended through small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. Projects funded by grants must comply with Title 40 requirements. Buy America provisions mandate that all iron, steel, and manufactured goods used in a project must be produced in the United States, with exceptions allowed under certain circumstances. The Buy America provisions require that iron, steel, and manufactured goods used in projects must be produced in the United States, with exceptions allowed if it's inconsistent with the public interest, not available in sufficient quantities or quality, or if it increases project costs by more than 25 percent. The Secretary must provide a detailed justification for any waivers granted. This must be done in a manner consistent with U.S. obligations under international agreements. The Secretary must ensure transparency and accountability in grant utilization, by making grant information public and submitting progress reports to Congress. Environmental reviews for projects funded by grants must be streamlined in coordination with relevant federal departments. The Secretary must coordinate with relevant federal departments to streamline environmental reviews for projects funded by grants. $985 billion is authorized for grants under the program from 2016 to 2020, with specific allocations for different project types. The program authorizes $985 billion for grants from 2016 to 2020, with specific allocations for different project types: 2% for projects in subparagraph (A), (B), or (C) of subsection (c)(1), 4% for projects in subparagraph (D), and 9% for projects in subparagraph (F) of subsection (c)(1). The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary may issue bonds up to $300 billion with specified terms. The proceeds will be used by the Transportation Secretary for the program outlined in the Act. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, detailing the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
